'version': '2025-01-09-base', 'language': 'en', 'pageNumber': 0, 'inputText': "Oregon Gov. Tina Kotek joined local leaders in declaring a 90-day state of emergency in Portland's Central City. (CNN) — Oregon leaders joined forces to declare a 90-day state of emergency in downtown Portland, funneling resources into fighting the city’s deadly fentanyl crisis. Oregon Gov. Tina Kotek, Multnomah County Chair Jessica Vega Pederson and Portland Mayor Ted Wheeler each made an emergency declaration to address the public health and public safety crisis in Portland’s Central City, citing overdoses, deaths and fear driven by fentanyl use, according to a Tuesday press release. “Our country and our state have never seen a drug this deadly and addictive, and all are grappling with how to respond,” Kotek said in the release. Oregon voters passed Measure 110 in 2020, which decriminalized some use of hard-drugs, including fentanyl, a potent synthetic opioid. The measure has received criticism, as opioid overdose deaths steadily climbed since. Opioid overdose deaths in the state increased from 280 in 2019 to 956 in 2022, according to the state’s data. Nearly 70,000 people in the US died of drug overdoses that involved fentanyl in 2021, almost a four-fold increase over five years, according to a US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention report released last spring. Fentanyl is significantly more likely to be involved in a deadly overdose than other common drugs, according to the CDC. Experts say reversing the trends in overdose deaths really depends on broader access to and use of treatments for opioid use disorder. The emergency declarations were recommended by a Portland Central City Task Force last year. “We are all in this together,” Kotek, a Democrat, said in the release. “The next 90 days will yield unprecedented collaboration and focused resources targeting fentanyl and provide a roadmap for next steps.” The emergency order allows the city, state and county to allocate resources to the response and stand up a command center in the central city. The effort will include two public health campaigns and increased outreach to get people into treatment, recovery and housing services. The release also cited the “continued missions between the Portland Police Bureau and Oregon State Police to hold individuals selling the drug accountable.” The command center will share and report data on the impacts of fentanyl in downtown and use the data to respond to “acute needs and gaps in service,” the release said. “We are acting with shared leadership to take urgent action today to respond to the very human toll fentanyl takes in our community, including overdoses, fatalities and day-to-day suffering, and the fear so many families are experiencing as a result,” Pederson said in the release. The-CNN-Wire ™ & © 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. All rights reserved. CNN’s Deidre McPhillips contributed to this report. Your browser is out of date and potentially vulnerable to security risks.We recommend switching to one of the following browsers:"}]

human.', 'document_classification': 'HUMAN_ONLY', 'version': '2025-01-09-base', 'language': 'en', 'pageNumber': 0, 'inputText': '(The Hill) — A Delaware judge ruled Tuesday that Tesla CEO Elon Musk must give up a 2018 bonus agreement that could be worth up to $55.8 billion, determining that it was not negotiated fairly. A group of Tesla shareholders sued Musk and the company after the company announced the bonus package, which grants Musk a 1 percent stake in the company for each of 12 stock price and revenue milestones laid out in the agreement. The bonuses could see his control over the company rise from 21 percent to 28 percent if all the milestones were met, which they eventually were. The shareholders claimed that the bonus’s massive size was because Musk effectively controlled the board, which granted it to him. Defendants described the deal as “high risk, high reward.” The bonus grant was the largest ever in the history of U.S. private business, Chancery Judge Kathaleen McCormick wrote, over 250 times larger than the median executive compensation at the time. McCormick described Musk’s “enormous influence” over the company’s board of directors and position as a “Superstar CEO.” She added that a shareholder vote to approve the bonus was also unreliable because the company misinformed shareholders. The judge called the process of constructing the bonus agreement “deeply flawed” due to extensive close ties with multiple members of the board that crafted it, adding that the process also landed at an “unfair price.” She determined that the bonus agreement should be rescinded. Business analysts have speculated that the ruling could mean that Musk loses his title as the richest man in the world. His net worth was previously estimated by Forbes to be about $210 billion. Tesla stock was down about 5 percent after hours on the news. The ruling adds to trouble at the company sparked by concerns over vehicle safety, specifically its self-driving software. Just after the ruling was published Tuesday, Musk chastised the court on X, formerly Twitter. “Never incorporate your company in the state of Delaware,” he said.'}]

(WSFA) - The Alabama Public Library Service has officially voted to not renew its membership with the American Library Association. The ALA is a librarian professional development organization that has recently come under fire in Alabama. Opponents contend it promotes Marxism, discriminates against faith-based organizations, and supports keeping sexual content in libraries. Gov. Kay Ivey threatened to cut funding to the state’s public libraries in October, saying she wants to restrict funds for libraries that don’t adopt policies to require more parental supervision in libraries. After the governor’s letter, the APLS sought to vote in November to disaffiliate from the ALA but postponed that action until Tuesday to study how breaking away from the group will impact local libraries. The states public library service voted to end its membership with the ALA because some members say the discourse became a distraction. Local public libraries, however, have their own membership with the organization. Some supporters of the decision to cut ties believe local libraries will follow in the state’s steps to end their own membership, but Hannah Reese with Clean Up Alabama says ending a membership is not enough. She’s calling for a complete disaffiliation from the ALA. “Just not renewing the membership is not what we’ve asked for,” Reese explained. :It’s the APLS having to go through what they’ve determined to be policy and reflecting on the influence of the ALA and what parts don’t reflect Alabama values.” Matt Layne, who serves as president of the Alabama Library Association said he feels like there’s “a bit of a manufactured outrage that’s occurred in our state regarding the American Library Association.” Tuesday’s decision is not the end of the ALA debate. At Ivey’s request, Wednesday marks the beginning of the process to that could change the state’s public library service administrative code, which requires local libraries to publicly renew and vote on memberships with the ALA. That’s something many libraries already do. The public can submit comments on those administrative changes starting Wednesday. Not reading this story on the WSFA News App? Get news alerts FASTER and FREE in the Apple App Store and the Google Play Store! Copyright 2024 WSFA. All rights reserved.'}]

the text is written entirely by a human.', 'document_classification': 'HUMAN_ONLY', 'version': '2025-01-09-base', 'language': 'en', 'pageNumber': 0, 'inputText': 'ROANOKE, Va. (WDBJ) - A 7-year-old boy fighting an illness his entire life has passed away, according to his family. Mikah Furrow had Congenital CMV, a common cause of birth defects in the U.S. The CDC reports that one of 200 babies is born with the disease, and one of five babies with CMV will have long-term health problems. Due to his illness, Mikah’s life in Vinton was marked by cerebral palsy, epilepsy, and developmental delays. His family placed him in hospice care a year ago, and in recent days, Mikah’s health took a turn for the worse, according to Carilion Hospice RN Case Manager Krysta Smoot. His family says he has gained his angel wings in a place where he can run, laugh and talk. “The essence of Mikah’s legacy resides in the collective memories, the wisdom gleaned from his remarkable journey, and the love he effortlessly instilled in those fortunate enough to have crossed his path.” “When he was born, we knew that he had CMV,” said his grandmother, Donna Furrow, and great aunt, Carlene Robinson. “But we had no idea the magnitude of what that meant.” “We made a decision together, that every day that he lived was going to be the best day of his life,” said Furrow and Robinson. “And that’s what it’s been.” Mikah’s family encourages every pregnant woman to ask her doctor for a CMV screening or seek information about it if considering having a baby. They believe this can reduce the severity and potentially save a child’s life. A memorial service and funeral are being planned. Copyright 2024 WDBJ. All rights reserved.'}]

(WJHG/WECP/Gray News) - Deputies in Florida were surprised by what they found after answering a call in the Baker area. Officials with the Okaloosa County Sheriff’s Office were called on Dec. 5 after two bear cubs were spotted on the side of Old River Road, but they didn’t look like the common northwest Florida black bears. It was later determined that the cubs were over 3,600 miles from their native home in Alaska. They were identified as Kodiak cubs, a unique species of brown or grizzly bears. The Okaloosa County Sheriff’s Office contacted bear experts at Florida Fish and Wildlife, who transported the cubs to a secure location while they investigated how they showed up in the area. Authorities found that the cubs escaped from a self-proclaimed bear trainer that kept them in an enclosure at a residence on Old River Road. The Florida resident now faces several wildlife violations. According to the Alaska Department of Fish and Game, Kodiak bears are the largest bears in the world. A large male Kodiak can stand over 10 feet tall on its hind legs and can weigh up to 1,500 pounds. Copyright 2024 WJHG via Gray Media Group, Inc. All rights reserved.'}]
